stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the session refining several Star Select screens: importing Biobak-made backgrounds, fixing fog/material issues, and coding a moving mine-cart animation while ensuring everything runs on real N64 hardware. General bug-fixing, performance checks, and ROM-size optimisation news are also discussed.

development_findings.summary: Arctic discovered that trimming unused audio after loop-points with his STRM64 tool frees about 1.7 MB of ROM, allowing more streamed music.
development_findings.quote: Arctic realised yesterday that his tool STRM64 saved 1.7 megabytes of ROM space, so we can have more streamed music than we thought.

development_findings.summary: Star-Select backgrounds must stay within ±32 768 world-units; exceeding that crashes real N64, so Kaze shortens geometry and fog range to fit.
development_findings.quote: If you render any object out of this range your N64 is just gonna crash.

development_findings.summary: Mine-cart Star-Select: Kaze writes spline code that increments 80 units per frame, adds pitch interpolation, and scrolls wheel textures; speed and scroll rate still being tuned.
Using global fog plus F3DEX2 microcode gives faster, cleaner rendering; incorrect microcode choice caused large display list and slow draw earlier.
development_findings.quote: If you use regular F3D the display list is a lot bigger and just renders a lot slower.

development_findings.summary: Replacing the Bubble Dome submarine model with Biobak’s improved version is planned for parity between level and Star-Select art.
Scrolling textures added directly in C rather than Fast64 export to keep display lists optimised.
Point-light engines (e.g., WiseCast) are avoided because they consume scarce iMEM; Kaze fakes point lights with vanilla SM64 lights instead.
development_findings.quote: Why don't I use point lights? They take an unnecessary amount of iMEM and I can just fake point lights with the original lights.

development_findings.summary: A possible Yoshi-racing minigame was dropped to keep scope manageable and hit 2024 release.
development_findings.quote: I realised it doesn't fit the scope of this game.

development_findings.summary: Arbitrary coding conventions (Pascal vs snake case, bool vs s32) are dismissed; Kaze prioritises compiler output and clarity over style rules.
development_findings.quote: There's no advantage or disadvantage to doing it either way; if anyone tells you otherwise they're an idiot.

development_findings.summary: Performance target remains full 60 FPS on real hardware; current second level and new backgrounds meet that budget after minor optimisation.
development_findings.quote: 64 MHz N64 should have no performance issues – nothing I do here is expensive to do.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and Zeina move into a new house next week; Kaze just accepted a 3D-modeling job for a government-related contractor.
YouTube revenue is low (~$6.90 last month) and Patreon only ‘a little’; game development is barely profitable.
context_findings.quote: My YouTube last month: $6.90 and a little bit on Patreon. I definitely cannot pay him enough to buy all his groceries.

context_findings.summary: He wants to compensate Biobak but cannot match real-job rates; open to discussing modest payment.
Kaze’s philosophy: quick irritation but rapid recovery; values practical solutions over suggested tooling, e.g., rejects EverDrive UART/Parallel Debug.
context_findings.quote: I seem angrier than I am – I'm just very easily irritated, but I also instantly don't care anymore.

context_findings.summary: He was banned from SMW Central for a joking, ‘base’ reply; cites it as a ‘funny story’.
context_findings.quote: I replied that I fucked the Dark Ones…it was a funny reply at the second – then I got banned.

context_findings.summary: Enjoys playful community memes (e.g., ‘Happy Cat’ song) but fears algorithmic content overload on social media.
Openly debates variable naming, compiler behaviour, and code readability on stream as part of his design ethos.

biobak.summary: Created multiple Star-Select background renders (Koopa Wave Cove, Koopa Carnival, Mouse Cave, Bubble Dome) and supplied mine-cart and submarine models.
Keeps a list of humorous Kaze quotes for potential sticker merch.
Helps re-work older levels and provides frequent artistic feedback during stream.

zeina.summary: Proposes Yoshi sticker pack concepts, suggests adding falling leaves or extra birds to backgrounds, and joins lighthearted on-stream banter.

key_stories.title: Audio-Space Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Arctic discovered excess data after loop-points in several streamed tracks. By trimming them, the team recovered 1.7 MB of ROM, giving freedom to include more music than expected.
key_stories.challenge: Strict 64 MB ROM limit restricted number of high-quality streamed songs.
key_stories.process: Arctic analysed STRM files with STRM64, identified unnecessary tail data, and scripted automatic trimming.
key_stories.outcome: 1.7 MB saved; music budget expanded without cutting content.
key_stories.key_quote: There were a few songs that kept going after the loop point and we didn't need that at all, so Arctic saved a few megabytes.

key_stories.title: Animating the Mine-Cart
key_stories.summary: Biobak delivered a mine-cart Star-Select design. Kaze had to code spline motion, texture scrolling, and safe N64 coordinate handling.
key_stories.challenge: Large model risked exceeding ±32 k coordinate range and initial animation logic caused jerky movement.
key_stories.process: Shortened geometry, wrote custom C spline routine (increment 80 u/f), added pitch interpolation and wheel texture scroll; iterated on speed and fog tuning.
key_stories.outcome: Working Star-Select sequence that showcases level theme while maintaining performance.
key_stories.key_quote: If you render any object out of this range your N64 is just gonna crash, so I have to shorten this whole thing.

key_stories.title: Can We Pay Biobak?
key_stories.summary: During stream, Biobak jokes about charging ‘$5 per vertex’ for art while Kaze admits revenue is minimal.
key_stories.challenge: Professional-quality art demands compensation but project budget is tiny.
key_stories.process: Kaze openly discusses YouTube/Patreon income and suggests talking payment off-stream.
key_stories.outcome: Payment discussion postponed; highlights indie-scene financial struggles.
key_stories.key_quote: My YouTube as it is is already barely even profitable…but you should be compensated somewhat.

open_questions.context: Arctic’s STRM64 optimisation frees ROM space.
questions: How does STRM64 integrate with your build process?
What criteria decide which tracks get streamed vs sequenced?
Will extra space change musical scope or quality targets?

open_questions.context: Multiple bespoke backgrounds with motion, fog, mine-carts, birds, etc.
questions: What narrative or emotional role do Star-Selects play in RTYI?
How do you balance N64 limits with modern aesthetic expectations?
Describe the typical art-code iteration loop between Biobak and Kaze.

open_questions.context: Avoidance of point-light engines to save iMEM.
questions: Can you elaborate on SM64’s original lighting pipeline and your custom hacks?
What scenes pushed you closest to hardware limits?
Would a modern microcode rewrite change your decisions?

open_questions.context: Kaze’s low revenue and new 3D job; unpaid collaborators.
questions: What are the team’s expectations around compensation and credit?
How does Kaze juggle day-job, marriage, and a large hobby project?
Has crowdfunding or publisher backing been considered?

open_questions.context: Brief mention of ban for ‘based’ reply.
questions: What actually happened in that thread?
How did that experience shape your community engagement approach?
Any lingering tensions with the ROM-hacking scene?

open_questions.context: Yoshi racing minigame cut; many feature ideas in chat.
questions: What framework do you use to decide which ideas make the cut?
Any past feature creep regrets?
How do you communicate scope limits to enthusiastic contributors?

open_questions.context: On-stream arguments over variable casing, debug tools.
questions: What core coding principles guide the project?
Why mistrust of certain community tools?
Has the decomp project’s structure influenced your own conventions?
